Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Disturbance and productivity as drivers of plant-pollinator diversity and function across scales
Award.AbstractNarration:
Despite the importance of wildfires in natural ecosystems, neither ecologists nor land managers fully understand how wildfire shapes biodiversity and ecosystem services across natural landscapes that vary in productivity. In this collaborative project, three early-career investigators will integrate field sampling, experiments, and modeling to understand how wildfires influence plant-pollinator networks in the Northern Rocky Mountains. The study will extend local plant-pollinator dynamics to regional scales across a productivity gradient, and will leverage a 30-year record of wildfires to investigate dynamics over longer periods than are possible using short-term experiments. The combination of broad spatial analyses with longer temporal records will provide unique insights into how wildfire shapes biodiversity and important ecosystem services across complex landscapes.

Billions of dollars are spent annually to suppress wildfires to protect the livelihoods of human societies within fire-prone landscapes. Simultaneously, huge investments are devoted to restoring fire without clear understanding of how it influences ecological interactions and the essential ecosystem services they provide. Results from this project will directly inform land management policy. The researchers will work closely with managers to develop and implement feasible forest management programs to optimize biodiversity and ecosystem function across complex environmental gradients. Courses in fire ecology and null models, a special session of the Montana Forest Restoration Committee, and mentorship of Hopa Mountain Native Science Fellows are planned in order to bring together diverse perspectives in ecology, management, policy, and native cultures. Students and a post-doctoral researcher will be involved in both research and outreach with government agencies, land managers, and the public. Together, this interdisciplinary team is poised to build relationships critical for solving some of the most pressing environmental issues at the interface of ecology and society.

This project is jointly funded by the Population and Community Ecology Program and the Office of the Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Among the many threats posed to biodiversity by global environmental change, changes to natural disturbance regimes are likely to have some of the most profound impacts on plants and animals and the ecosystem services they provide. Wildfires have played a critical role in maintaining the structure and function of many ecosystems worldwide. However, humans have altered natural wildfire regimes through fire suppression and by increasing wildfire severity. Despite the importance of wildfires in natural ecosystems, neither ecologists nor land managers fully understand how or why wildfire affects biodiversity and ecosystem services across complex landscapes that vary in environmental conditions.

 

Pollination is an essential ecosystem service required for plant and animal populations to persist in complex landscapes. Yet the ways in which wildfire affects plant and pollinator communities, plant-pollinator interactions, and pollination services are poorly understood, especially at the large landscape scales most germane to conservation and land management. In our project, we aimed to better understand the ecological processes that underlie responses of plants, pollinators, and pollination services to changes in wildfire severity and resource availability in the Northern Rocky Mountains, a biodiverse but understudied region of critical conservation importance.

 

We found that wildfires, fire severity, and resource availability strongly influence the species composition and diversity of plant and pollinator communities. Across three sites that vary in resource availability, we compared species composition and diversity of plants and pollinator communities among unburned forests and forests burned with mixed-severity and high-severity wildfires. Species diversity of flowering plants and some groups of pollinators (particularly bees) was higher in burned forests compared to unburned forests at the sites with low and moderate resource availability, but similar in burned and unburned forests at the site with high resource availability. Plant species diversity was also higher in mixed-severity fire compared to high-severity fire, but only at the site with low resource availability. Moreover, mixed-severity fire generally promoted greater variation in species composition of plants and pollinators than high-severity fire. These findings indicate that historical, mixed-severity fire regimes increase biodiversity by promoting the persistence of different types of species across a diverse mosaic of habitats. Our results also demonstrate the importance of resource availability in determining responses of plants and pollinators to changes in wildfire regimes across complex landscapes.

 

We also found that wildfires have contrasting effects on the composition and diversity of plants and pollinators through time. Forests with older fires supported higher plant species diversity and densities of flowers compared to forests with more-recent fires or unburned forests. In contrast, more-recent fires supported the highest bee diversity. Wildfire age also influenced plant species composition, resulting in different types of species in forests with recent fires, old fires, and unburned forests. Bee species composition was also influenced by fire age, but the species composition of bee and plant communities responded differently to fire age. These findings suggest that plant and pollinator communities re-assemble differently after fire. In turn, differences in the assembly of plant and pollinator communities after fire are likely to have important effects on plant-pollinator interactions and pollination services.

 

The results of our research apply directly to pressing questions in the mountain West about the effects of wildfire on conservation, land management, and restoration of forest ecosystems. Billions of dollars are spent annually to suppress wildfires and to protect the livelihoods of human societies within fire-prone landscapes. Simultaneously, huge investments are devoted to restoring fire without clear understanding of how it influences plant-pollinator interactions and pollination services. Our results have helped to inform the development of forest-management programs designed to promote biodiversity and ecosystem services across complex landscapes of the mountain west. For example, by sharing our findings with federal land managers across the region, we have contributed ecological science to management plans, with the dual aim of maintaining biodiversity of plants and pollinators while restoring environmental complexity representative of historical fire regimes.

 

Our project has provided research and training opportunities for 40 people, including 5 graduate students (3 women, 1 Latina), 16 undergraduate students (9 women, 1 Native American), 15 research technicians (11 women), and 2 postdoctoral researchers. Our research team contributed to scientific outreach by teaching a course in fire ecology and workshop in computer programming, participating in a special session of the Montana Forest Restoration Committee, providing numerous public talks, mentoring Native American students through the Hopa Mountain Native Science Fellows Program, and providing a two-day Pollinator Workshop at Salish Kootenai College (the Tribal College of the Confederated Salish and Kootenai Tribes) to students, faculty, and tribal employees on the Flathead Reservation. These activities provided early-career researchers with opportunities to develop skills in science communication through interactions with government agencies, land managers, and the public. Our outreach activities have fostered relationships critical for solving some of the most pressing environmental issues at the interface of ecology and society.
